title: Field-Resilient Supercurrent Diode in a Multiferroic Josephson Junction
authors:
Hung-Yu Yang, Joseph J. Cuozzo, Anand Johnson Bokka, Gang Qiu,
  Christopher Eckberg, Yanfeng Lyu, Shuyuan Huyan, Ching-Wu Chu, Kenji
  Watanabe, Takashi Taniguchi, Kang L. Wang
abstract:
The research on supercurrent diodes has surged rapidly due to their potential
applications in electronic circuits at cryogenic temperatures. To unlock this
functionality, it is essential to find supercurrent diodes that can work
consistently at zero magnetic field and under ubiquitous stray fields generated
in electronic circuits. However, a supercurrent diode with robust field
tolerance is currently lacking. Here, we demonstrate a field-resilient
supercurrent diode by incorporating a multiferroic material into a Josephson
junction. We first observed a pronounced supercurrent diode effect at zero
magnetic field. More importantly, the supercurrent rectification persists over
a wide and bipolar magnetic field range beyond industrial standards for field
tolerance. By theoretically modeling a multiferroic Josephson junction, we
unveil that the interplay between spin-orbit coupling and multiferroicity
underlies the unusual field resilience of the observed diode effect. This work
introduces multiferroic Josephson junctions as a new field-resilient
superconducting device for cryogenic electronics.
